{{Infobox civilian attack | title = 1991 Drumbeg killings | partof = [[the Troubles]] |map = {{Location map|Northern Ireland |width = 250 |lat = 54.447222 |long = -6.388333 |marksize = 5 |caption = }} | location = Drumbeg estate in [[Craigavon]],
[[County Armagh]],
[[Northern Ireland]] | date = 28 March 1991 | time = | timezone = [[Greenwich Mean Time|GMT]] | type = shooting | weapons = [[Browning Hi-Power|9mm Browning pistol]] | fatalities = 3 [[Irish Catholic]] civilians | injuries = | perp = [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] (using the cover-name [[Protestant Action Force]] )
[[UVF Mid-Ulster Brigade]]
[[Billy Wright (loyalist)|Billy Wright]] (ordered attack) }} {{Campaignbox Northern Ireland Troubles|state=collapsed}} On the 28 March 1991 the [[Ulster Loyalist|Loyalist paramilitary]] organization the [[Ulster Volunteer Force]] (UVF) carried out a gun attack on a mobile shop in the Drumbeg estate in the town of [[Craigavon]] in [[County Armagh]] shooting dead three [[Irish Catholics|Catholic civilians]]. Two of those killed were teenage girls.{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=28&month=03&year=1991|author=Malcolm Sutton|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk|title=CAIN: Sutton Index of Deaths|accessdate=5 January 2018}} It is believed that the former [[Loyalist Volunteer Force]] leader and at that time in 1991 [[UVF Mid-Ulster Brigade]] commander [[Billy Wright (loyalist)|Billy Wright]] had planned and ordered the attack. Those killed were Eileen Duffy (19), Katrina Rennie (16) and Brian Frizzell (29). ==Background== The year 1991 during [[The Troubles]] saw a return to the tit-for-tat sectarian killings between [[Irish Republican]] and [[Ulster Loyalist]] paramilitaries that plagued [[Belfast]], Armagh and other places in [[Northern Ireland]] during the mid 1970s which saw hundreds of both Catholic and Protestant civilians killed.{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch75.htm|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk|title=CAIN: Chronology of the Conflict 1975|accessdate=5 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch76.htm|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk|title=CAIN: Chronology of the Conflict 1976|accessdate=5 January 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch77.htm|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk|title=CAIN: Chronology of the Conflict 1977|accessdate=5 January 2018}} Just three weeks earlier, in the [[1991 Cappagh killings]], the UVF carried out a gun attack on a pub in the staunchly Republican [[County Tyrone]] village of [[Cappagh, County Tyrone|Cappagh]], killing one civilian and three IRA members.{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=3&month=03&year=1991|author=Malcolm Sutton|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk|title=CAIN: Sutton Index of Deaths|accessdate=5 January 2018}} ==Shooting== The two teenage girls who were killed were sitting behind the counter in the mobile shop along with a third teenage girl, Jamie Smith. There was several people in the shop at the time and the girls were talking among themselves. A van pulled up outside the shop and a masked gunman wearing military style clothing, armed with a 9mm Browning pistol, jumped out. One of the people in the shop presuming it was [[Irish Republicanism|Republicans]] yelled "Provisional IRA, hit the floor!". Most people managed to escape, but the three girls were stuck and trapped behind the counter. The gunman pulled Jamie Smith by the hair calling her a "[[Fenian]] slut" and then threw her out of the shop. The UVF gunman then shot Duffy and Rennie, killing them both. While the attack was taking place, Brian Frizzell walked into the shop, and was shot as the gunman was leaving the store.{{cite web|url=http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/othelem/chron/ch91.htm#28391|website=cain.ulst.ac.uk|title=CAIN: Chronology of the Conflict 1991|accessdate=5 January 2018}} Eileen's brother Brendan Duffy was one of the first at the shop after the attack, he described the scene: "Brian Frizzell was lying in a pool of blood. Katrina was still sitting on the crate. She was dead but her blue eyes were wide open and there was a bullet wound on her neck. Eileen was slumped on the floor, shot in the head. Her face was badly swollen and blood was pumping out of her head and ears. I tried to resuscitate her but in my heart I knew she was gone. I was so numb, I couldn't cry." {{cite web|url=http://www.nuzhound.com/articles/breen/arts2011/sep18_Eileen_Duffy_murder_evidence_destroyed__SBreen_Sunday-World.php|website=nuzhound.com|title=Newshound: Links to daily newspaper articles about Northern Ireland|accessdate=5 January 2018}} ==Aftermath== The killings drew widespread condemnation from both the [[Irish Catholics|Catholic]] and [[Protestantism in Ireland|Protestant]] communities in Northern Ireland. The funerals were attended by thousands of people. It's believed the killings of Protestant civilians Derek Patterson on the 9 April & Ian Sproule on the 12 April were in retaliation to the Drumbeg killings. http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=13&month=04&year=1991 http://www.apnewsarchive.com/1991/IRA-Says-It-Killed-Relative-Of-Legislator/id-63727dcdd20b39f86e2b9cc86b2a9679 Aaron Edwards - UVF: Behind The Mask p.203 Eight months after the attack three more civilians were killed by the UVF in the Craigavon area at the Carbet Road-Carn Road junction. Desmond Rogers (54), Fergus Magee (28), and John Lavery (27) were shot dead, Rogers and Magee were Catholics, Lavery a Protestant. The three men were shot in their car after being stopped at an illegal UVF checkpoint (a similar tactic to that used by the UVF in the [[Miami Showband killings]]1975). The UVF later apologized for killing the Protestant man. http://cain.ulst.ac.uk/cgi-bin/dyndeaths.pl?querytype=date&day=14&month=11&year=1991In October 1992, a man, Vicky Ahitty (24), from Portadown, was charged with these and other murders and firearms possession.{{cite news|title=Man in court over Ulster killings|work=The Independent (Jason Bennetto, 25 October 1992)|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/man-in-court-over-ulster-killings-1559543.html|accessdate=4 December 2011|location=London, UK|date=25 October 1992}} In 1992, Tom Harper was charged with the Drumbeg mobile shop murders, although he was the driver and not the gunman. He was given a life sentence for his part in the murders.{{cite web|title=Murder accused from town|work=Lurgan Mail (24 August 2010)|url=http://www.lurganmail.co.uk/news/local/murder_accused_from_town_1_1781673|accessdate=4 December 2011}} The attack was ordered by [[Billy Wright (loyalist)|Billy Wright]], but the gunman has never been charged. Local allegations of security force collusion remain and it was noted that, on the night of the shooting, the normally heavy police presence was not apparent. In September 2011, the PSNI announced that records of interviews with suspects in key murder investigations from 1985 to 1993 had been destroyed in 1998 as the place they were stored was contaminated with asbestos. They included the records in this case.{{cite web|title=No justice for mobile shop murder families after evidence is destroyed|work=Sunday World (Suzanne Breen, 18 September 2011)|url=http://www.nuzhound.com/articles/breen/arts2011/sep18_Eileen_Duffy_murder_evidence_destroyed__SBreen_Sunday-World.php|accessdate=4 December 2011}} ==UTV Documentary on killings== *{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lhnE-ILNJuE&t=22s|publisher=youtube.com|title=Mobile shop killings Drumbeg, Craigavon 1991|accessdate=6 January 2018}} ==See also== * [[Avenue Bar shooting]] * [[1991 Cappagh killings]] * [[Loughinisland massacre]] * [[Timeline of Ulster Volunteer Force actions]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist|2}} {{The Troubles|state=collapsed}} {{Ulster Volunteer Force}} {{coord missing|County Armagh}} [[Category:Ulster Volunteer Force actions]] [[Category:Terrorist incidents in 1991]] [[Category:1991 crimes in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:1991 in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Massacres in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Police misconduct in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Deaths by firearm in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:Murder in 1991]] [[Category:Mass shootings in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Spree shootings in Northern Ireland]] [[Category:March 1991 events]] [[Category:Military actions and engagements during the Troubles (Northern Ireland)]] [[Category:The Troubles in County Armagh]]

{{About|the author of ''Liber Horn'' (1311)|the film director|Andrew Horn (filmmaker)}} [[File:Andrew Horn, Mirroir des iustices (1st ed, 1642, title page).jpg|thumb|The title page of the first edition of Andrew Horn's ''[[:File:Andrew Horn, Mirroir des iustices (1st ed, 1642).pdf|Mirroir des iustices]]'' (1642),<ref name="Mirror 1642">{{citation|author=Andrew Horn|authorlink=Andrew Horn|title=[[:File:Andrew Horn, Mirroir des iustices (1st ed, 1642).pdf|La somme appelle Mirroir des iustices: vel Speculum Iusticiariorum, Factum per Andream Horne]]|location=London|publisher=Printed by E[dward] G[riffin] for Matthew Walbanke and Richard Best and are to be sold at their shops at [[Gray's Inn|Grayes Inne Gate]]|year=1642|oclc=84157087}}.</ref> written in [[Anglo-Norman language|Anglo-Norman]] and Latin]]
'''Andrew Horn''' ({{circa|1275}}–1328) was a [[fishmonger]] of Bridge Street, [[London]], lawyer and legal scholar. He served as [[Chamberlain of London|Chamberlain of the City of London]] from 1320 until his death in 1328.<ref name="StephenLee1908">{{cite DNB|wstitle=Horn, Andrew|volume=27}}</ref><ref name="(England)Riley1868">{{cite book|author1=Corporation of London|last2=Riley|first2=Henry Thomas|authorlink2=Henry Thomas Riley|title=Memorials of London|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BCdOAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA116|accessdate=10 February 2012|year=1868|publisher=Longmans, Green and Co.|page=116}}</ref> Sir [[William Blackstone]]'s ''[[Commentaries on the Laws of England]]'' describe Horn as "one of the most learned lawyers of his day".<ref name="Blackstone1996">{{cite book|last1=Blackstone|first1=Sir William|authorlink1=William Blackstone|last2=Tucker|first2=St. George|authorlink2=St. George Tucker|title=Blackstone's commentaries|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=p9h6WJXuqJUC&pg=PR59|accessdate=12 February 2012|year=1996|publisher=The Lawbook Exchange, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-886363-16-8|page=59}}</ref>
Horn is best known for his book ''[[Liber Horn]]'', compiled in 1311. Besides coroners' reports and other mundane matters, ''Liber Horn'' contains some of the earliest and most reliable versions of early English laws, including certain ''[[Statutes of uncertain date]]'' and an annotated copy of the [[Magna carta#The Great Charter 1297: Statute|Magna Carta of 1297]].<ref name="SharpeCommittee1913">{{cite book|first1=Reginald Robinson|last1=Sharpe|last2=City of London (England). Court of Common Council. Library Committee|title=Calendar of coroners rolls of the city of London, A.D. 1300-1378|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=yWdMAAAAMAAJ&pg=PR5|accessdate=8 February 2012|year=1913|publisher=R. Clay and Sons|page=5}}</ref> Horn is also thought to have compiled and edited ''La somme appelle Mirroir des justices: vel Speculum justiciariorum'' (translated variously as ''[[The Mirror of Justices]]'' or ''The Mirror of Justice'').<ref name="Plucknett2001">{{cite book|last=Plucknett|first=Theodore Frank Thomas|authorlink=Theodore Plucknett|title=A concise history of the common law|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=maGWTVyY-ykC&pg=PA267|accessdate=10 February 2012|year=2001|publisher=The Lawbook Exchange, Ltd.|isbn=978-1-58477-137-1|page=267}}</ref><ref>[https://archive.org/details/mirrorofjustices00hornrich The Mirror of Justice]</ref><ref name="PollockRandall1897">{{cite book|author1=Sir Frederick Pollock|authorlink1=Sir Frederick Pollock, 3rd Baronet|author2=Alfred Edward Randall|title=The Law quarterly review|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PPQuAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA85|accessdate=10 February 2012|year=1897|publisher=Stevens and Sons|pages=85–103}}</ref>
Horn was a member of the [[Worshipful Company of Fishmongers]].<ref name="CookHarwood1861">{{cite book|last1=Cook|first1=John Douglas|authorlink1=John Douglas Cook|last2=Harwood|first2=Philip|last3=Pollock|first3=Walter Herries|authorlink3=Walter Herries Pollock|first4=Frank|last4=Harris|first5=Harold|last5=Hodge|title=The Saturday review of politics, literature, science and art|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Xy0_AQAAIAAJ&pg=PA196|accessdate=10 February 2012|year=1861|publisher=John W. Parker and Son|page=196}}</ref>
==Works== As a legal scholar, Andrew Horn's literary achievements consisted largely of compiling, editing, transcribing, and annotating statutes, pipe rolls, chronicles, and other official documents. This has resulted in a problem of attribution, since it is not always clear to what extent he acted as author or editor.
*''Liber Horn''. *''Mirroir des Justices'' (''Mirror of Justices''). *A continuation of ''Leges Anglorum''. *''Liber legum regum antiquorum''. *A narrative of the London [[eyre (legal term)|eyre]] of 1321. *''Annales Londonienses''.
==Notes== {{Reflist|20em}}
==External links== *[http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/13780 Oxford Dictionary of National Biography]

[[File:Ендру Росос.jpg|thumb|mini|right|Andrew Rossos]] '''Andrew Rossos''' is a [[Macedonian Canadian]] ٰProfessor Emeritus of History at the [[University of Toronto]].<ref>[http://hsozkult.geschichte.hu-berlin.de/rezensionen/2008-4-042.pdf Rezension für H-Soz-Kult von Stefan Troebst, Geisteswissenschaftliches Zentrum Geschichte und Kultur Ostmitteleuropas (GWZO), Universität Leipzig - "Macedonia and the Macedonians: A History"'', 2008] (in German). Citation: ''Rossos selbst ist makedonischer Herkunft, geboren im zu Griechenland gehörigen Ägäisch-Makedonien.'' in English: ''Rossos himself is of Macedonian origin, born in Aegean Macedonia belonging to Greece''.</ref>
==Biography== Rossos was born in 1941 in the village of [[Moschochori, Florina|Moschochori]], [[Florina (regional unit)|Florina]], [[Greece]]. During the [[Greek Civil War]] in 1948, he was evacuated to [[Czechoslovakia]] as a [[Refugees of the Greek Civil War|refugee child]]. Rossos attended primary school in [[Sobotin]] and Technical School in [[Prague]]. In 1958 he moved with the rest of his family to [[Canada]] and graduated from high school in [[Toronto]]. Rossos earned a [[bachelor's degree]] in history at [[Michigan State University]] in 1963 and did his postgraduate studies at the [[University of Stanford]], earning his [[PhD]] in 1971. Since then he has worked at the [[University of Toronto]] and became a [[professor]] there in 1982.<ref>Македонска енциклопедија. Скопје, 2009, т.ІІ, 1282.</ref>
At the end of 2008, his book ''Macedonia and the Macedonians: A History'' was published. He authored a monograph on [[Russian foreign policy]] in the [[Balkans]] titled ''Russia and the Balkans: Inter-Balkan Rivalries and Russian Foreign Policy, 1908-1914''. Rossos is an adherent of the views espoused by the [[historiography in the Republic of Macedonia|national historiography of the Republic of Macedonia]],<ref>[http://hsozkult.geschichte.hu-berlin.de/rezensionen/2008-4-042.pdf Recension from Professor Stefan Troebst about Rossos's book: Macedonia and the Macedonians. A History, 2008]</ref> which is highly politicized, because the Macedonian nation-building process has not yet been accomplished.<ref>Historein, Vol 4 (2003), Serving the Nation: Historiography in the Republic of Macedonia (FYROM) after Socialism. Ulf Brunnbauer, p. 175, {{DOI|10.12681/historein.86}}</ref>
==Bibliography== * "The Disintegration of Yugoslavia, Macedonia's Independence, and Stability in the Balkans." In War and Change in the Balkans: Nationalism, Conflict, and Cooperation, edited by Brad K. Blitz. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 2006. * {{cite journal | year = 2000 | title = Great Britain and Macedonian Statehood and Unification, 1940-49 | url = | journal = East European Politics and Societies | volume = 14 | issue = 1| pages = 119–142 | doi=10.1177/0888325400014001006}} * {{cite journal | year = 1997 | title = Incompatible Allies: Greek Communism and Macedonian Nationalism in the Civil War in Greece, 1943-1949 | url = | journal = Journal of Modern History | volume = 69 | issue = 1| pages = 42–76 | doi=10.1086/245440}} * "The British Foreign Office and Macedonian National Identity, 1918-1941." In National Character and National Ideology in Interwar Eastern Europe, edited by Ivo Banac and Katherine Verdey. New Haven: Yale Center for International and Area Studies, 1995. * {{cite journal | year = 1991 | title = The Macedonians of Aegean Macedonia: A British Officer's Report, 1944 | url = | journal = Slavonic and East European Review | volume = 69 | issue = 2| pages = 282–309 }} *[http://makedonika.wordpress.com/2008/07/15/the-british-foreign-office-and-macedonian-national-identity-1918-1941/ ''The British Foreign Office and Macedonian National Identity, 1918-1941''] (Slavic Review, 1994) *[http://makedonika.wordpress.com/2008/07/15/incompatible-allies-greek-communism-and-macedonian-nationalism-in-the-civil-war-in-greece-1943-1949/ ''Incompatible Allies: Greek Communism and Macedonian Nationalism in the Civil War in Greece, 1943-1949''] *''Macedonia and the Macedonians: A History'' (2008)
==References== {{Reflist}}

[[Image:AntoniusSanderus.jpg|thumb|Antoon Sanders]] [[File:Sanderus - Frontispies FI.png|thumb|Front page of the first edition (1641) of the ''[[Flandria Illustrata]]'']] '''Antonius Sanderus''' (15 September 1586 – 10 January 1664) was a [[Flanders|Flemish]] Catholic cleric and historian.
==Biography== Sanderus was born "Antoon Sanders", but like all writers and scholars of his time he Latinized his name. Having become master of philosophy at the [[University of Douai]] in 1609, he studied theology for some years under [[Johannes Malderus]] (Jan van Malderen) at the [[Old University of Leuven|University of Leuven]], and [[Willem Hessels van Est]] (Estius) at Douai, and was ordained [[priest]] at [[Ghent]].
For some years he was engaged in parochial duties, and combated the [[Anabaptist]] movement in Flanders with great zeal and success. In 1625 he became secretary and [[almoner]] of Cardinal [[Alfonso de la Cueva, 1st Marquis of Bedmar|Alfonso de la Cueva]], later becoming [[Canon (priest)|canon]] and [[scholaster]] of [[St Martin's Cathedral, Ypres]]. Publication of the first volume of his sumptuously illustrated ''Flandria illustrata'' (1641) nearly bankrupted him, and he was rescued from ruination by an award of 1,000 florins through the [[Lille Chamber of Accounts]].<ref>Jules Finot (ed.), ''Inventaire sommaire des archives départementales antérieures à 1790. Nord. Archives Civiles, série B. Chambre des Comptes de Lille'', vol. 6 (Lille, 1888), p. 165.</ref> Further such subventions in support of his work followed in 1645, 1651, 1655 and 1662.<ref>Finot, ''Inventaire sommaire'', vol. 6, pp. 178, 205, 231, 273.</ref>
In 1654 he was appointed [[Canon penitentiary|penitentiary]] at [[Ypres]]. After three years, however, he resigned this office to devote himself entirely to scientific, and especially to historical studies. He soon found himself compelled to claim the hospitality of the [[Benedictine]] [[Abbey]] of Afflighem, since he had reduced himself to absolute poverty by the publication of numerous works.
==Writings== He combined high intellectual gifts with great zeal, and left behind forty-two printed, and almost as many unprinted, works. The most important are the following: * ''De scriptoribus Flandriae libri III'' (Antwerp, 1624) * ''De Gandavensibus eruditionis fama claris'' (Antwerp 1624) * ''De Brugensibus eruditionis fama claris libri II'' (Antwerp, 1624) * ''Hagiologium Flandriae sive de sanctis eius provinciae liber unus'' (Antwerp, 1625; 2nd ed., Lille, 1639).
A general edition of these four works appeared under the title: ''Flandria illustrata'' (2 volumes, Cologne, 1641–44; The Hague, 1726).
Of his other works may be mentioned: * ''Elogia cardinalium sanctitate, doctrina et armis illustrium'' (Louvain, 1625) * ''Gandavium sive rerum Gandavensium libri VI'' (Brussels, 1627) * ''Bibliotheca belgica manuscripta'' (2 parts, Lille, 1641-3) * ''Chorographia sacra Brabantiae sive celebrium in ea provincia ecclesiarum et coenobiorum descriptio, imaginibus aeneis illustrata'' (Brussels, 1659; The Hague, 1726); this is his chief work.
==References== {{Reflist}} *[http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/13435c.htm newadvent.org]

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2016}} {{Use New Zealand English|date=November 2016}} '''Arthur Herbert Carman''' (2 August 1902 – 28 November 1982) was a New Zealand sports journalist and writer, bookseller, publisher, [[pacifist]], local politician, and local historian.
He was born and died in [[Wellington]], New Zealand.<ref name="DNZB Carman">{{DNZB|title=Arthur Herbert Carman|first= David|last= Grant|id=4c8|accessdate= }}</ref> He was born in [[Paparangi]], [[Johnsonville, New Zealand|Johnsonville]], and lived in [[Tawa, New Zealand|Tawa]] (originally called Tawa Flat). In 1932 Carman moved to Ranui in Tawa, with his new wife Edith Clark; they lived at No 7 Iti Street, Linden. Arthur had been in the Audit Department but, hankering for a bureaucracy free life, decided to become a [[Lambton Quay]] bookseller. They liked the countryside, although Ranui had barely formed metal roads and it was quicker for Edith to push the pram along the rail tracks to Tawa, picking up lumps of coal en route. Arthur caught the morning train to the shop. He started the agitation for a station at [[Linden railway station, New Zealand|Linden]] to avoid having to pull the emergency cord to alight at Linden.<ref>{{cite book |last= Cassells |first= Ken R. |title= Tawa: Enterprise and Endeavour |accessdate= |edition= |origyear= |year= 1988 |publisher= Tawa Borough Council |location= Wellington |isbn= 0-473-00715-0 |oclc= |page= 59 |pages= }}</ref>
He was a bookseller and publisher (as '''Wright and Carman''', founded by his father Walter Carman); his [[Lambton Quay]] bookshop was a landmark and meeting place for thirty years. ''Arthur Carman Street'' in [[Paparangi]] is named after him.
He was on several local bodies: the [[Wellington Hospital Board]], the Tawa Borough Council and the Hutt Valley Power and Gas Board. He stood unsuccessfully as an independent for the [[Wellington City Council]] in [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1941|1941]] and [[Wellington City mayoral election, 1944|1944]], and also for [[Wellington North (New Zealand electorate)|Wellington North]] in the [[New Zealand general election, 1943|1943 general election]], his only avenue to debate pacifism legally in wartime New Zealand.<ref name="DNZB Carman"/>
He published sports books as Arthur Carman (''The New Zealand Rugby Almanack'', ''The New Zealand Cricket Almanack''; both annuals) and local history books as '''A. H. Carman''' or '''Arthur H. Carman'''. These included ''The Birth of a City: Wellington 1840-1843'' and ''Tawa Flat and the Old [[Porirua]] Road'', which went into three editions (1956, 1970, 1982)
He was noted as a [[Christian pacifism|Christian pacifist]], and spent some months in [[Miramar Peninsula|Mt Crawford]] prison in Wellington, NZ in 1941, for 'subversion' when he attempted to publicly espouse the Christian pacifist view. His viewpoint had changed from traditional [[Methodism]] toward [[Quakerism]] following a 1925 visit to the [[World War I]] battlefields (he had been touring the United Kingdom as the sole press correspondent travelling with the [[1924–25 New Zealand rugby union tour of Britain, Ireland and France|'Invincibles' All Black rugby team]]), although he remained a Methodist local preacher for the whole of his life.
A biography was published in 2011, by [[Bruce Murray (cricketer)|Bruce Murray]] and David Wood: ''Arthur Carman's Suitcase: The Life and Times of Arthur Herbert Carman''.<ref name="Carman's Suitcase">{{cite web |last1=Dando |first1=Kris |title=Old suitcase a treasure for Tawa historian |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/dominion-post/news/local-papers/kapi-mana-news/5197534/Old-suitcase-a-treasure-for-Tawa-historian |website=stuff.co.nz |accessdate=7 July 2018}}</ref>

The '''Baby Scoop Era''' was a period in [[anglosphere]] history starting after the end of [[World War II]] and ending in the early 1970s,[http://www.babyscoopera.com The Baby Scoop Era Research Initiative] characterized by an increased rate of [[Premarital sex|pre-marital pregnancies]] over the preceding period, along with a higher rate of newborn [[adoption]]. ==History== ===In the United States=== From 1945 to 1973, it is estimated that up to 4 million parents in the [[United States]] had children placed for adoption, with 2 million during the 1960s alone.{{cite web |url=http://darkwing.uoregon.edu/~adoption/topics/adoptionstatistics.htm |title=Adoption Statistics |last1= |first1= |last2= |first2= |date= |website=The Adoption History Project |publisher=University of Oregon |accessdate=17 October 2014}} Annual numbers for non-relative adoptions increased from an estimated 33,800 in 1951 to a peak of 89,200 in 1970, then quickly declined to an estimated 47,700 in 1975.Pelton, L. (1988). "The Institution of Adoption: Its Sources and Perpetuation" in ''Infertility and Adoption, A Guide for Social Work Practice'', Deborah Valentine, Editor. (pp. 88–89)[http://www.uoregon.edu/~adoption/archive/MazaAT.htm Maza, P.L. (1984). Adoption trends: 1944–1975.] Child Welfare Research Notes #9. Washington, D.C.: Administration for Children, Youth, and Families, 1984. (This does not include the number of infants adopted and raised by relatives.) In contrast, the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services|U.S. Department of Health and Human Services]] estimates that only 14,000 infants were placed for adoption in 2003.[http://www.childwelfare.gov/pubs/s_place.cfm U.S. Department of Health and Human Services, Child Welfare Information Gateway (2005). Voluntary Relinquishment for Adoption: Numbers and Trends] This period of history has been documented in scholarly books such as ''Wake Up Little Susie'' and ''Beggars and Choosers'', both by historian [[Rickie Solinger]], and social histories such as the book ''[[The Girls Who Went Away]]'' and the documentary, ''[[A Girl Like Her]]'', based on the book by Ann Fessler. Fessler is a professor of photography at the [[Rhode Island School of Design]] who exhibited an [[art installation]] titled ''The Girls Who Went Away''. It is also the theme of the documentary "Gone To A Good Home" by [[Film Australia]]. Beginning in the 1940s and 1950s, [[illegitimacy]] began to be defined in terms of psychological deficits on the part of the mother.Solinger, R. (2000). ''Wake Up Little Susie: Single Pregnancy and Race Before Roe v. Wade.'' (p. 88) At the same time, a liberalization of sexual mores combined with restrictions on access to [[birth control]] led to an increase in premarital pregnancies.Petrie, A. (1998). ''Gone to an Aunt's: Remembering Canada's Homes for Unwed Mothers.'' (pp. 7–8) The dominant psychological and social work view was that the large majority of unmarried mothers were better off being separated by adoption from their newborn babies.O'Shaughnassy, T. (1994). ''Adoption, [[Social Work]], and Social Theory'' (p. 115) According to Mandell (2007), "In most cases, adoption was presented to the mothers as the only option and little or no effort was made to help the mothers keep and raise the children".[http://www.wpunj.edu/newpol/issue42/Mandell42.htm Mandell, B. (2007). "Adoption."] ''New Politics'', Vol. 11, No. 2, Winter 2007, Whole No. 42 Solinger describes the social pressures that led to this unusual trend, explaining that women who had no control over their reproductive lives were defined by psychological theory as "not-mothers", and that because they had no control over their reproductive lives, they were subject to the ideology of those who watched over them. As such, for unmarried pregnant girls and women in the pre-''[[Roe v. Wade|Roe]]'' era, the main chance for attaining home and marriage rested on their acknowledging their alleged shame and guilt, and this required relinquishing their children, with more than 80% of unwed mothers in maternity homes acting in essence as "breeders" for adoptive parents.Solinger, R. (2000). ''Wake Up Little Susie: Single Pregnancy and Race Before Roe v. Wade.'' (p. 95) According to Ellison, from 1960 to 1970, 27 percent of all births to married women between the ages of 15 and 29 were conceived [[Premarital Sex#United States|premaritally]]. This problem was thought to be caused by female [[neurosis]], and those who could not procure an [[Abortion in the United States|abortion]], legally or otherwise, were encouraged to put up their children for adoption.{{cite journal|author=Ellison, M.|year=2003|title=Authoritative Knowledge and Single Women's Unintentional Pregnancies, Abortions, Adoption and Single Motherhood: Social Stigma and Structural Violence|journal=Medical Anthropology Quarterly|volume=17|issue=3|page=326|pmid=12974201|doi=10.1525/maq.2003.17.3.322}} In popular usage, singer Celeste Billhartz uses the term "baby scoop era" on her website to refer to the era covered by her work "The Mothers Project."{{cite web|title=About The Mothers Project ...|author=Celeste Billhartz|work=The Mothers Project|url=http://www.themothersproject.com/about/aboutTMP.html}} A letter{{cite web|url=http://www.billfinch.org/blog/archive/2006_04_09_archive.html |title=More Adoption Support |date=April 15, 2006 |work=BillFinch.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071016172238/http://billfinch.org/blog/archive/2006_04_09_archive.html |archivedate=2007-10-16 |df= }} on Senator [[Bill Finch (politician)|Bill Finch]]'s website uses the term as well. Writer Betty Mandell references the term in her article "Adoption".{{cite journal|title=Adoption|author=Betty Reid Mandell|url=http://nova.wpunj.edu/newpolitics/issue42/Mandell42.htm|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080922060843/http://www.wpunj.edu/newpol/issue42/Mandell42.htm|archivedate=September 22, 2008 |deadurl=no|volume=XI|number=2|journal=New Politics}} The term was also used in a 2004 edition of the ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]''.Lohmann, B. "World of Adoption; Forced to Give Up Her Baby, She Now Opposes Adoption," ''[[Richmond Times-Dispatch]]'', November 21, 2004, p. G-1. Infant adoptions began declining in the early 1970s, a decline often attributed to the decreasing birth rate, but which also partially resulted from social and legal changes that enabled middle-class mothers to have an alternative [[single mother]]hood. The decline in the fertility rate is associated with the introduction of [[Combined oral contraceptive pill|the pill]] in 1960, the completion of legalization of [[birth control|artificial birth control]] methods, the introduction of [[Title X|federal funding]] to make [[family planning]] services more available to the young and low income, and the legalization of abortion. Brozinsky (1994) speaks of the decline in newborn adoptions as reflecting a freedom of choice embraced by youth and the women's movement of the 1960s and 1970s, resulting in an increase in the number of unmarried mothers who parented their babies as opposed to having them taken for adoption purposes. "In 1970, approximately 80% of the infants born to single mothers were [...] [taken for adoption purposes], whereas by 1983 that figure had dropped to only 4%."Brozinsky, A. (1994). "Surrendering an Infant for Adoption: The Birthmother Experience". In ''The Psychology of Adoption'', D. Brozinsky and M. Schechter (Eds.). New York: Oxford University Press. (p. 297) In contrast to numbers in the 1960s and 1970s, from 1989 to 1995 fewer than 1% of children born to never-married women were surrendered for adoption.Chandra, A., Abma, J., Maza, P., & Bachrach, C. (1999). [https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/data/ad/ad306.pdf "Adoption, adoption seeking, and relinquishment for adoption in the United States"]. Advance Data (No. 306) from Vital and Health Statistics of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, National center for Health Statistics, U.S. Department of Health and Human Services. Retrieved February 16, 2005. ===In the Commonwealth=== A similar social development took place in the [[United Kingdom]],[http://www.uktrackers.co.uk/ti_survey.htm Trackers International, "Survey 1000"] [[New Zealand]],Shawyer, J. (1979). ''Death by Adoption'' [[Australia]],Moor, M. (2007). ''[http://www4.gu.edu.au:8080/adt-root/public/adt-QGU20070111.172012/index.html Silent Violence: Australia's White Stolen Children]''. A thesis submitted in fulfilment of the requirement for the Doctorate of Philosophy in Arts, Media and Culture at Griffith University, Nathan, Qld. and [[Canada]].Petrie, A. (1998). ''Gone to an Aunt's: Remembering Canada's Homes for Unwed Mothers''. ====In Canada==== Canada's "Baby Scoop Era" refers to the postwar period from 1945 to 1988, when over 400,000 unmarried pregnant persons, mostly aged 15–19 (usually Caucasian), were targeted for their yet-to-be-born infants, simply because they were unmarried with a child. A large number of these young women were confined as inmates in maternity group homes, which were managed by religious orders, such as the [[The Salvation Army, Canada|Salvation Army]], the [[Catholic Church in Canada|Catholic Church]], the [[United Church of Canada|United Church]] and the [[Anglican Church of Canada|Anglican Church]] etc. These maternity "homes" were heavily funded by the [[Government of Canada|Canadian government]]. There were over 70 maternity homes in Canada which housed between 20 and 200 pregnant women at a time. In Canadian maternity "homes" and hospitals, up to 100% of newborns were removed from their legal mothers after birth and given up for adoption purposes. These newborns were taken under a Health and Welfare protocol.{{cite journal|last1=Williams|first1=Leigh Ann|title=Taken|journal=Anglican Journal|date=May 13, 2014|url=http://www.anglicanjournal.com/articles/taken|accessdate=July 20, 2014}} Some professionals of the era considered that the punishment of the mother for her transgression was an important part of the process. Dr. Marion Hilliard of [[Women's College Hospital]] was quoted in 1956 saying:
The father plays absolutely no part in this. That is part of her rehabilitation. When she renounces her child for its own good, the unwed mother has learned a lot. She has learned an important human value. She has learned to pay the price of her misdemeanor, and this alone, if punishment is needed, is punishment enough...We must go back to a primary set of values and the discipline that starts with the very small child.Dorothy Howarth, “Mothers not all unhappy”, ''The Toronto Telegram'', November 22, 1956.
The term Baby Scoop Era is similar to the term [[Sixties Scoop]], which was coined by Patrick Johnston, author of ''Native Children and the Child Welfare System''.[http://research2.csci.educ.ubc.ca/indigenation/Indian_ReACTions/Indian_ReACTions/SixtiesScoop.htm Reder, D. (2007). ''Indian re:ACT(ions)''] University of British Columbia "Sixties Scoop" refers to the Canadian practice, beginning in the 1960s and continuing until the late 1980s, of apprehending unusually high numbers of Native children over the age of 5 years old from their families and fostering or adopting them out.[http://www.eyeweekly.com/eye/issue/issue_01.13.00/news/nation.php Lyons, T. (2000). "Stolen Nation,"] in ''Eye Weekly'', January 13, 2000. Toronto Star Newspapers Limited. A similar event happened in Australia where Aboriginal children, sometimes referred to as the [[Stolen Generation]], were removed from their families and placed into internment camps, orphanages and other institutions. ====In Australia==== A similar period of [[forced adoption in Australia|forced adoption]], also known as the "White Stolen Generations", also occurred in Australia. It is generally understood that a decline of adoption during the 1970s was linked to a 1973 law providing for financial assistance to single parents.Parliamentary Paper No. 366, Standing Committee on Social Issues, Report on Adoption Practices, Second Interim Report, Transcripts of Evidence, 16 June 1999 – 25 October 1999 ==Portrayals in media== *''A girl like her'' documentary film (2011) *''Gone To A Good Home (Film Australia 2006)''. A [[Film Australia]] National Interest Program in association with Big Island Pictures. Produced in association with the Pacific Film and Television Commission and SBS Independent. *''Everlasting: The Girls Who Went Away'' by Ann Fessler. Described as "a multi-channel, surround-sound audio installation based on oral history interviews Ann Fessler conducted with women who surrendered a baby for adoption in the 1950s and 1960s (as described in the "[http://calendar.duke.edu/calendar.nsf/EventID/74T9A9 Calendar," Duke University], retrieved October 22, 2007) *''The Other Mother: A Moment of Truth Movie (1995) (TV)'' Director: Bethany Rooney. Writers (WGA): Carol Schaefer (book), Steven Loring. *''[[The Magdalene Sisters]]'' (2002) Director: Peter Mullan, Writer: Peter Mullan *''Love, War, Adoption (2007)'' Directed by Suzie Kidnap. == References == {{Reflist|2}} ==Further reading== * Aston, Jonny. "Yours Hopefully," {{ISBN|978-0-646-57639-8}} written and published by Jonny Aston. A personal account of teenage pregnancy, adoption and reunion, portraying 1960s social attitudes and prejudices. * Buterbaugh, K. "[http://www.eclectica.org/v6n1/buterbaugh.html Not by Choice]," ''Eclectica'', August 2001. * Buterbaugh, K. "[http://www.moxiemag.com/moxie/articles/perspectives2.html Setting the Record Straight]", ''Moxie Magazine'', April 2001. * Fessler, A. (2006). ''The Girls Who Went Away; The Hidden History of Women Who Surrendered Children for Adoption in the Decades Before Roe v. Wade''. New York: Penguin Press. {{ISBN|1-59420-094-7}} * Kunzel, R. (1995). ''Fallen Women, Problem Girls: Unmarried Mothers and the Professionalization of Social Work, 1890–1945'' (Yale Historical Publications Series) (Paperback). Ann Arbor, MA: Yale University Press (August 30, 1995) {{ISBN|0-300-06509-4}} * Mandell, B. (2007). [http://www.wpunj.edu/newpol/issue42/Mandell42.htm "Adoption."] ''New Politics'', 11(2), Winter 2007, Whole No. 42. * Petrie, A. (1998). ''Gone to an Aunt's: Remembering Canada's Homes for Unwed Mothers''. Toronto: * McLelland and Stewart. {{ISBN|0-7710-6971-5}} * Moor, M. (2007). ''[http://www4.gu.edu.au:8080/adt-root/public/adt-QGU20070111.172012/index.html Silent Violence: Australia's White Stolen Children]''. A thesis submitted in fulfilment of the requirement for the Doctorate of Philosophy in Arts, Media and Culture at Griffith University, Nathan, Qld. [http://www4.gu.edu.au:8080/adt-root/uploads/approved/adt-QGU20070111.172012/public/02Whole.pdf] * O'Shaughnassy, T. (1994). ''Adoption, Social Work, and Social Theory''. Brookfield: Ashgate Publishing. {{ISBN|1-85628-883-8}} * Shawyer, J. (1979). '' Death by Adoption.'' Cicada Press. {{ISBN|0-908599-02-1}} * Solinger, R. (2000). ''Wake Up Little Susie: Single Pregnancy and Race Before Roe v. Wade''. New York: Routledge. {{ISBN|0-415-92676-9}} * Solinger, R. (2001). ''Beggars And Choosers: How The Politics Of Choice Shapes Adoption, Abortion And Welfare In The U.S.'' (Hill and Wang) * Terranova, D. (2014). ''Baby Farm''. Brisbane: Terranova Publications. {{ISBN|978-0-9941700-0-2}}. A novel about forced adoptions in Australia in the 1970s. {{Adopt}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Baby Scoop Era}} [[Category:Adoption history]] [[Category:Historical eras]]

{{Coord|43|8|28|N|80|16|5|W|display=title}} {{infobox military memorial | name = Bell Telephone Memorial | body = City of Brantford | image = [[Image:Alexander Graham Bell Brantford Monument 0.98.jpg|300px]] | caption = The Bell Telephone Memorial frontside | commemorates = the [[invention of the telephone]] | coordinates = 43°8′27.94″ N 80°16′4.88″ W | nearest_town = [[Brantford, Ontario]] | designer = [[Walter Seymour Allward]] | inscription = Commemorating the invention of the telephone at Brantford by Alexander Graham Bell in 1874 | unveiled = 24 October 1917}}
The '''Bell Memorial''', also known as the '''Bell Monument''' and '''Telephone Monument''', is a memorial designed by [[Walter Seymour Allward]] to commemorate the [[invention of the telephone]] by [[Alexander Graham Bell]] at the [[Bell Homestead National Historic Site]], in [[Brantford, Ontario]], [[Canada]].
In 1906, the citizens of the Brantford and [[County of Brant|Brant County]] areas formed the Bell Telephone Memorial Association, which commissioned the memorial. By 1908, the association's designs committee asked sculptors on two continents to submit proposals for the memorial. The submission by Canadian sculptor [[Walter Seymour Allward]] of [[Toronto]] won the competition. The memorial was originally scheduled for completion by 1912 but Allward, aided by his studio assistant [[Emanuel Hahn]] did not finish it until five years later. The [[Governor General of Canada]], [[Victor Cavendish, 9th Duke of Devonshire]], unveiled the memorial on 24 October 1917.
Allward designed the monument to symbolize the telephone's ability to overcome great distances. A series of steps lead to the main section where the floating allegorical figure of ''Inspiration'' appears over a reclining male figure representing ''Man, transmitting sound through space'', discovering his power to transmit sound through space, and also pointing to three floating figures, the messengers of ''Knowledge'', ''Joy'', and ''Sorrow'' positioned at the other end of the tableau. Additionally, there are two female figures mounted on granite pedestals representing ''Humanity'' positioned to the left and right of the memorial, one sending and the other receiving a message.
The Bell Memorial has been described as the finest example of Allward's early work. The memorial itself has been used as a central fixture for many civic events and remains an important part of Brantford's history. It was provided a heritage designation under the ''[[Ontario Heritage Act]]'' in 2005 and listed on the [[Canadian Register of Historic Places]] in 2009.<ref>{{citation |url=http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/rep-reg/place-lieu.aspx?id=10785 |title=Bell Monument |publisher= Canadian Register of Historic Places }}</ref>
== History ==
[[Alexander Graham Bell]] conceived the technical aspects of the telephone and [[Invention of the telephone|invented it]] in July 1874, while residing with his parents at their farm, Melville House, now a [[National Historic Site of Canada]].{{sfn|Bruce|1990|pp=122-123}}<ref>{{citation |last=Patten |first=William |title=Pioneering the Telephone in Canada |year=1926 |location=Montreal| publisher=Herald Press}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|Melville House, a name created by Alexander Melville Bell on his stationary, was at the time part of Tutelo Heights on the outskirts of the City of Brantford, but which was later incorporated within the city.|group="Note"}} One of the first successful voice transmissions of any notable distance was made on 4 August 1876, between the telegraph office in Brantford, Ontario and Bell's father's homestead over makeshift wires.{{sfn|MacLeod|1999|p=14-18}} He later refined the telephone's design at Brantford after producing his first working prototype in [[Boston]].{{sfn|MacLeod|1999|p=14}} Canada's first telephone factory, created by [[Thomas Cowherd#Earliest telephone production|James Cowherd]], was located in Brantford, and operated from about 1879 to 1881 leading to the informal designation as ''The Telephone City''.{{sfn|Sharpe|1998|p=80}}
===Memorial association established===
Discussion of a monument to commemorate both Bell and his invention was first raised in Brantford in 1904 although the Bell Telephone Memorial Association was not formally established until 1906. After gaining Bell's approval, the association and its proposed memorial were publicly endorsed on 9 March 1906 at a banquet in Brantford Kirby House (later to become the Hotel Kirby), which Bell attended as a guest of honour.<ref name="BEX-1947.05.03" /> That same year the association was formally organized and incorporated by an Act of the [[Legislative Assembly of Ontario|Legislature of Ontario]] with the stated aim of commemorating the invention of the telephone in Brantford and to name Bell as its inventor.<ref name="Whitaker">{{citation |last=Whitaker |first=A.J. |title=Bell Telephone Memorial and Bell Homestead |url=http://www.telephonetribute.com/pdf/bell_memorial_booklet.pdf |publisher=City of Brantford/Hurley Printing |year=1944 |location=Brantford, Ontario|ref=harv}}</ref> What was highly unusual in this instance was the building of an important monument to a living person, an event usually conducted only for imperial leaders.<ref name="SanJoseEN-1907.11.01" /> The duality of the monument with its dedication to both the inventor and to his invention, with its emphasis on the latter, likely persuaded Alexander Graham Bell, normally modest, to accept the invitation to its public unveiling.<ref name="BEX-1975.05.01">{{cite news |title=How Citizens Built the Bell Memorial 58 Years Ago |work=Brantford Expositor |date=1975-05-01}}</ref>
The association was organized with the support of [[King George V|George, Prince of Wales]] (later King George V), [[Viceroy of India]] and former Governor-General of Canada [[Gilbert Elliot-Murray-Kynynmound, 4th Earl of Minto]], and the latter's successor Governor-General [[Albert Grey, 4th Earl Grey]], plus an approximate dozen other prominent leaders in Canada and the United States, who endorsed the project with their backing.<ref name="Whitaker" /> [[Donald Howard, 3rd Baron Strathcona and Mount Royal]] became its first honorary president and upon his death, he was succeeded by the [[Prince Arthur, Duke of Connaught and Strathearn]], a former Governor-General of Canada.<ref name="Expositor" /> [[William Foster Cockshutt]], the local federal [[Member of Parliament (Canada)|Member of Parliament]] who had originally proposed the memorial in 1904, became the association's president, and was assisted by another MP, [[Lloyd Harris (politician)|Lloyd Harris]], who served as vice-president.<ref>{{citation |last=Muir |first=Gary |url=http://brantford.library.on.ca/localhistory/pdfs/cockshuttfamily.pdf |title=Bits and Pieces of Brantford's History: The History of the Cockshutt Family |accessdate=2012-05-21}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|The assosation members are itentified as W.F. Cockshutt as President, Lloyd Harrisas Vice-President, George Hateley as Secretary, John Muir as Treasurer, W.N. Andrews, Edward L. Goold, George Kippax, G.H. Muirhead, T.H. Preston, F.D. Reville, A.J. Wilkes, K.C., C.H. Waterous, Brantford Mayor J.W. Bowlby and Warden A.B. Rose|group="Note"}} The design selection committee was led by [[Byron Edmund Walker]], a prominent Canadian banker, philanthropist and patron of the arts.<ref name="Unveiling" /><ref name="Expositor-2009.12.27" />
The Association's public appeal quickly raised {{CA$|35000}} within its first months, rising to $44,000 by September 1909, eventually collecting over $65,000 through donations from various citizens worldwide.<ref name="BEX-1909.09.29" /><ref name="BEX-1916-07-18">{{cite news |title=The Bell Memorial |work=Brantford Expositor |date=1916-07-18}}</ref> An additional federal contribution of $10,000 was supported in Canada's parliament by [[Prime Minister of Canada|Prime Minister]] [[Wilfrid Laurier|Sir Wilfrid Laurier]].<ref name="SanJoseEN-1907.11.01">{{cite news |title=Monument Proposed to Inventor of the Telephone: Unusual Honor |work=San Jose Evening News |date=1907-11-01 |page=9}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Telephone's Birth Memorial |work=Poverty Bay Herald' |volume=XXXIV |issue=10963 |date=1907-04-01 |page=3}}</ref>{{#tag:ref| Other significant contributions were made by the 'American Telephone Company' of Boston (possibly referring to the head of the [[Bell System]], [[AT&T Corporation|AT&T Corp.]] – $1,000), Col. [[William Foster Cockshutt|W.F. Cockshutt]], M.P. ($500), Goold, Shapely & Muir ($500), [[Waterous Engine Works Co. Ltd.|Waterous Engine Works Co.]] ($500), Verity Plow Company ($500), [[Cyrus Hall McCormick II#Biography|Mrs. McCormick]] of Chicago ($500), [[Bell Telephone Company of Canada]] ($500), the [[Toronto|City of Toronto]] ($500), and even a long-time personal and business rival of Alexander Graham Bell and Bell Telephone, inventor [[Thomas Edison]], who provide a donation of $250.<ref name="BEX-1936-08-10">{{cite news |title=Tribute to Bell Is Very Impressive: Subscriptions Were of an International Character |work=Brantford Expositor |date=1936-08-10}}</ref> |group="Note"}} In a city with a population of only 30,000, the fundraising needed for the monument was a major accomplishment.<ref name="BEX-1975.05.01" />
=== Selection committee choice === [[File:Bell Memorial concept drawing -c.1909.jpg|thumb|right|An '''early concept drawing''' of the memorial and the Alexander Graham Bell Gardens, c.1909.]]
Invitations were sent out to 22 sculptors in Europe, the United States and Canada in 1908, inviting them to submit models for the proposed monument.<ref name="Expositor-2010.07.26">{{cite news |last=Ruby |first=Michelle |url=http://www.brantfordexpositor.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2685265 |title=Bell Homestead: Descendants On Hand To Mark Centennial |work=Brantford Expositor |date=2010-07-26 |accessdate=2012-04-12}}</ref> By May 1909 either nine or ten models had been submitted.{{#tag:ref|The Whitaker booklet states nine models,<ref name="Whitaker" /> while Elgin-Balfour writes that ten models were submitted to the committee.<ref name="Elgin-Balfour">{{citation |publisher=Elgin-Balfour Foundation |url=http://www3.brantford.ca/inventory.nsf/e6a90eb030f9a3d485256cfe006dc8bf/5e7fc98d512c1dc185256a8b0058610b/$FILE/The%20Sampler%20on%20Bell%20Memorial.doc |title=The Sampler A Book About Brantford |year=1977 |pages=69–71}}</ref> After the competition's completion, five of the plaster models where deposited at the [[Bell Homestead National Historic Site|Bell Homestead]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Bell Homestead |work=Brantford Courier |date=1911-07-22}}</ref>|group="Note"}} A designs committee was appointed by the association and selected the three best designs they favored from the models submitted. The committee asked a trio of outside judges, Sir [[Byron Edmund Walker]] of the [[Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce]] in Toronto, New York State Senator [[George Allen Davis]] of Buffalo and Sir George Christie Gibbons of London, Ontario to make a final decision, all of whom were considered patrons of the arts.<ref name="Whitaker" /><ref name="Expositor">{{citation|last=Marquis |first=T.G. |url=http://brantford.library.on.ca/localhistory/pdfs/1909expositor.pdf |title=Brantford, The Telephone City |work=The Greater Brantford Expositor |year=1909 |pages=13–14}}</ref> After consideration a unanimous choice was made to award the commission to [[Walter Seymour Allward]].{{#tag:ref|The committee's second and third choices were for the designs submitted by [[George William Hill (sculptor)|G.W. Hill of Montreal]], and A.E. Pausch of Buffalo, N.Y. who worked with designs of Castar Craun of Berlin, Ontario.<ref name="BEX-1916-07-18" />|group="Note"}} The millionaire banker and philanthropist Sir Byron Walker was likely persuasive in swaying the unanimous decision to the sculptor. Walker had earlier contacted a prominent Brantford banker, praising Allward's previous works, and advised him that "because of the national character of the work I am particularly interested in the best possible outcome artistically".<ref name="Marshall.thesis">{{citation |last=Marshall |first=Barbara Ruth |url=http://circle.ubc.ca/bitstream/handle/2429/34424/UBC_1971_A8%20M37.pdf?sequence=1 |title=Sir Edmond Walker, Servant of Canada |publisher=University of British Columbia |date=June 1971}}</ref>
=== Lengthy delays and completion ===
The commission award for the memorial had been made in 1908 and a contract to Allward authorized in 1909, based on an initial cost estimate of $25,000 with the provision that the work would be completed by 1912.<ref name="BEX-1916-07-18" /><ref name="BEX-1909.09.29">"Bell Memorial Plans", ''[[Brantford Expositor]]'', 29 September 1909.</ref> Also in 1909 the association purchased [[Alexander Melville Bell]]'s former homestead and farm, Melvile House, and transferred its ownership to the City of Brantford for conversion into a museum.<ref name="BEX-1947.05.03">"Bell Memorial Committee Set Up Here In 1906", ''[[Brantford Expositor]]'', 3 May 1947.</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Bell Memorial Beautiful Tribute to Telephone And Its Noted Inventor, Alexander Graham Bell |work=Brantford Expositor |date=1926-04-24}}</ref>
Allward was assisted by his studio assistant, [[Emanuel Hahn|Emanuel Otto Hahn]], another highly notable sculptor who worked on the monument with him until 1912 when Hahn left for the [[Ontario College of Art]]. The project proceeded slowly in part due to Allward's concurrent work on several other commissions at the same time, including the [[South African War Memorial (Toronto)|South African War Memorial]], a major monument erected in Toronto. In April 1915 Allward reported to the committee that the two heroic figures to be mounted on pedestals had been successfully cast and that foundation work for the site had been tendered. But in regards to the central bronze casting, which was to become the largest ever created in North America up to that point,<ref>{{cite news |title=Fine Monuments Perpetuate Glorious Memories |work=Brantford Expositor |date=1937-08-07}}</ref> he could not estimate when it would be complete, writing in a letter "I am giving all my time to it; I cannot do more. It is an important panel and cannot be too well done".<ref>{{cite news |title=Bell Memorial Directors Met: Reports Were Received On Progress of Work But Date of Unveiling is Not Yet Fixed |work=Brantford Expositor |date=1915-04-22}}</ref> For various reasons the memorial was not completed until 1917, with [[World War I]], material shortages, an embargo on exports of French moulding sand and transportation limitations creating lengthy delays.<ref name="BEX-1916-07-18" />
=== Unveiling of the Memorial === [[File:Unveiling of the Bell Telephone Memorial, October 24, 1917, in Brantford, Ontario Canada.jpg|thumb|right|The unveiling of the Bell Memorial in October 1917, with Bell and dignitaries.]] The Brantford monument was finally unveiled in a driving rain on 24 October 1917 by then Governor General of Canada [[Victor Cavendish, 9th Duke of Devonshire]] before an audience in the thousands.<ref name="Unveiling" />{{sfn|McMeal|1917|p=21}} The Governor General of Canada arrived in the city by train, along with the [[Lieutenant-Governor of Ontario]] Sir [[John Strathearn Hendrie|John Hendrie]], the Hon. Senator Robertson of the [[Privy Council]], the Hon. W.D. McPherson of the [[Government of Ontario|Ontario Government]] and other notables. They were greeted by a children's chorus, honour guards, the band of the [[125th (Brantford) Battalion]] and the chimes of Grace Anglican Church located only a few dozen metres from the memorial. Also in attendance in full war regalia was Chief A.R. Hill of the [[Six Nations of the Grand River First Nation|Six Nations Tribes of the Grand River]], where Bell, not long after his arrival in Canada, had been made an honorary tribal chief.{{#tag:ref|Not long after the extended Bell family arrived in Canada, Alexander Graham discovered the [[Six Nations 40, Ontario|Six Nations Reserve]] across the river at [[Onondaga (village)|Onondaga]], where he learned the [[Mohawk language]] and translated its unwritten vocabulary into [[Visible Speech]] symbols. For his work, Bell was awarded the title of Honorary Chief and participated in a ceremony where he donned a [[Mohawk nation|Mohawk]] headdress and performed traditional dances.{{sfn|Groundwater|2005|p=35}}|group="Note"}}
[[File:Bell family at memorial with Bell Mem Assoc.jpg|thumb|left|Bell in centre, with committee members, his granddaughter, [[Mabel Harlakenden Grosvenor]]; his wife, [[Mabel Gardiner Hubbard|Mabel Hubbard]]; and his eldest daughter Elsie.]]
As a public holiday had been declared for the unveiling, the city's normal activities were shut down for the entire day.<ref name="Globe-1917.10.26">{{cite news|work=The Globe |title=Inventor of the Telephone Upholds Brantford's Claim |date=1917-10-25 |page=5}}</ref> After the Governor-General completed his address at the monument and unveiled its shrouds, he withdrew to the city's Old Opera House due to the driving rain, along with large numbers of the crowd. The ceremonies were continued indoors in the city's opera theatre, with Bell addressing the audience again twice more at both the opera house and during a formal reception meal held at the Kerby House. Others spoke with Bell, including his former associate from the [[Aerial Experiment Association]], [[J.A.D. McCurdy]], [[Gilbert Hovey Grosvenor|Gilbert Grosvenour]], president of the [[National Geographic Society]], and other dignitaries.<ref name="Unveiling" /><ref name="Globe-1917.10.26" />
Alexander Graham Bell (in both of his addresses that day) reminded the attendees that "Brantford is right in claiming the invention of the telephone here... [which was] conceived in Brantford in 1874 and born in Boston in 1875",{{sfn|Bruce|1990|pp=482–483}} and later addressing the Duke, said "...on behalf of the Association ...in presenting to His Excellency [with] a silver telephone... I hope that in using it he will remember that the telephone originated in Brantford and that the first transmission to a distance was made between Brantford and Paris."<ref name="Whitaker" /><ref name="Unveiling" />{{#tag:ref|The silver telephone Bell presented to the [[Governor-General of Canada]] was identical to one presented earlier in 1901 by Bell's father, [[Alexander Melville Bell]], to the [[Prince of Wales]] (later [[George V|King George V]]) in Brantford, during the prince's visit to Canada.<ref name="Globe-1917.10.26" />{{sfn|Reville|1920|p=311}}|group="Note"}}<ref>http://brantford.library.on.ca/files/pdfs/localhistory/bellmemorial.pdf</ref> In appreciation to the people of Brantford, Bell's wife, [[Mabel Gardiner Hubbard|Mabel Hubbard Bell]], made a contribution of $500 to the city's support fund for its soldiers then fighting in Europe.<ref name="Vancouver Daily Sun-1917.11.18">{{cite news|title=Canada in Review |work=Vancouver Daily Sun |date=1917-11-18}}</ref>
== Memorial ==
At the time of its unveiling, the memorial was one of the most impressive monuments of the day in Canada, designed to depict the vast distances on the Earth being "annihilated" by the telephone. The allegorical style of the monument's figures depicts several aspects of the telephone in its worldwide use. Its most striking feature is its broad, main bronze cast panel, approximately seven and a half metres wide and two and a half metres high, which portray "....the elusive dream of the inventor's youth—Inspiration whispering to Man, his power to transmit sound through space.{{#tag:ref|The bronze tableau contains three figures in [[Relief|''alto-rilievo relief'']] and measures approximately 773 centimetres in width by 250 centimetres in height. According to documents, its casting process 'taxed' the existing foundry capabilities of the era. |group="Note"}} Three ephemeral ghostly figures, two of which are cast in mid-relief and one in [[Relief|high (''alto-rilievo'') relief]], depict ''Knowledge, Joy'' and ''Sorrow'', transmitted to man by the telephone. Two heroic figures flanking the broad flight of steps leading up to the monument symbolize humanity sending and receiving a message."<ref>Raymond, E.T. [http://brantford.library.on.ca/localhistory/pdfs/telephonecity.pdf Brantford, The Telephone City], Brantford War Memorial Association.</ref>
The Memorial is located within the Bell Memorial Gardens of Bell Memorial Park at 41 West Street in the City of Brantford.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.brantford.ca/residents/leisurerecreation/parkstrails/parks/Pages/BellMemorialPark.aspx |title=Bell Memorial Park |publisher=Brantford.ca |date=1917-10-24 |accessdate=2017-09-01}}</ref> The monument itself is located on a gore of land forming a near-triangularly shaped public park. The triangular plot of land in front of the monument was transformed into a park, with its embankments being sodded. The panel in front of the gore which contains the monument is a smaller gore which has been artistically laid out as a park, the entire area being named as the Bell Memorial Gardens.<ref name="Whitaker" />
=== The model of ''Man, transmitting sound through space'' ===
[[File:Bell Telephone Memorial, Alexander Graham Bell Park, Brantford, Ontario, Canada - IMG 0387.JPG|thumb|right|'''Allegorical 'Inspiration' and 'Man', communicating''', with the vastness of the Earth depicted by the curvatures on its cast bronze panel.]]
The model for'' 'Man, discovering his power to transmit sound through space','' was Cyril William George Kinsella a wounded war veteran and a former resident of [[Brantford]].<ref name="Unveiling" /><ref name="Expositor-2009.12.27" /> Kinsella served as Allward's nude model representing Man after being severely injured in the European conflict.<ref name="Allward">{{citation |last=Allward |first=W.S. |url=http://www3.brantford.ca/inventory.nsf/e6a90eb030f9a3d485256cfe006dc8bf/5e7fc98d512c1dc185256a8b0058610b/$FILE/WSAllward%20on%20bell%20memorial.doc |title=Sketch-Model No.8: Description to Accompany Sketch Model of Proposed Bell Telephone Memorial |accessdate=2012-04-12}}</ref> Born in the UK he had become one of approximately 100,000 disadvantaged British children and orphans, a "[[Home Children|Home Child]]", sent to Canada and other [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth countries]] to find better lives in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. After arriving in Ontario in 1908 he resided in a series of Fegan Homes (named after James William Condell Fegan of Britain), including one in Toronto where he likely later met Allward. Kinsella eventually settled in Brantford County to perform farmwork. Underaged, but a healthy {{convert|178|cm|ftin}} in height in 1914, he enlisted in Brantford's 125th Battalion for service overseas where he fought in Belgium and France with the [[Canadian Expeditionary Force]] during World War I.<ref name="Expositor-2009.12.27" />
Kinsella was wounded and shell-shocked at the [[Second Battle of Ypres]] in [[Belgium]] and, after being invalided and discharged back to Canada in 1916, met Allward in Toronto while convalescing and then worked as his model, saying later "The posing was exacting and took about two months."<ref name="BX-1946.05.04" /> Kinsella subsequently became bored with civilian life and reenlisted with the Canadian Army, returning to Europe. He was serving with the [[1st Canadian Division]], [[4th Battalion (Central Ontario), CEF|Fourth Battalion]] near the northern French village of St. Marie Chappell at the time of the memorial's unveiling in Brantford. He later returned to Canada at the end of the war, but did not view himself on the memorial until 27 years later, in May 1946.<ref name="Expositor-2009.12.27">{{cite news |last=Ball |first=Vincent |url=http://www.brantfordexpositor.ca/ArticleDisplay.aspx?e=2237256 |title=The Industrialist, The Architect And The Home Boy |work=Brantford Expositor |date=2009-12-27 |accessdate=2012-04-23}}</ref><ref name="BX-1946.05.04">{{citation|work=Brantford Expositor |title=War Veteran Sees For First Time The Bell Memorial Figure He Had Posed For |date=1946-05-04}}</ref>
=== Other monument features ===
At the memorial's crest is a series of steps leading to the main portion of the monument, a wide mass of white Stanstead granite, faced by the largest single [[Lost-wax casting|bronze casting]] created up to that time, which taxed the capacity of its foundry. The sculptor sought to bring out, as the dominant note, the discovery by man of his power to transmit sound through space. Above the reclining figure of man is ''Inspiration'',{{#tag:ref|Most literature refers to this figure as ''Inspiration'', however in an explanation of the complex allegories by Sir Edmund Walker, he named the figure surmounting ''Man, discovering his power to transmit vocal sounds through space'' as ''Intelligence''.<ref name="Marshall.thesis" />|group="Note"}} urging him on to greater endeavors, while, at the other end of the panel are the messengers of ''Knowledge'', ''Joy'' and ''Sorrow'', communicating to man by telephone. On both sides of the main portion of the monument are two "heroic" female figures representing humanity in bronze on granite mounts, one depicted in the act of sending, the other of receiving a message over the telephone. The two female figures were positioned some distance apart in order to denote the telephone's power to traverse great distances. Uniting the entire work together is the line of the earth's curvature on the bronze casting, depicting the extent of the telephone's worldwide use.<ref name="Historica" /> Allward's original proposed design for the monument also included the flags of the greatest nations of the world,<ref name="Allward" /> a modern element that was likely omitted as it would detract from the monument's neoclassical design.
The rear side of the monument contains a small stone foundation with bullfrog [[gargoyle]]s; while cut in the stone, on pilasters, are representations of the [[British Crown]] and the [[Maple leaf|Maple Leaf]]. On the rear, also, was placed a bronze plaque giving the names of the patrons and the executive committee of the Association. In the present day the plaque is now found on the side of the rightmost granite mount for one of the heroic figures. The foundation, steps, pedestals and walls are composed of durable Stanstead granite.<ref name="Whitaker" /> On the main portion, to the right and left, two circular panels are inscribed: "''Hoc Opus Machinae Patri Dedicatum Est''" (this monument has been dedicated to the author of the invention) and "''Mundus Telephonici Usu Recreatus Est.''" (the world has been recreated using the telephone).<ref name="Unveiling">Brant Historical Society. [http://brantford.library.on.ca/archive/index.php/archive/article/189 The Unveiling of the Bell Memorial in Brantford, Ontario, October the Twenty-Fourth, 1917] (monograph), Brantford, ON: commissioned by [[Judge|Justice]] Alexander D. Hardy of the Bell Memorial Association, on behalf of the Brant Historical Society, 1917. Includes transcripts of addresses made by speakers and by Bell himself. Retrieved from Brantford.Library.on.ca March 27, 2012.</ref><ref name="B.H.S.-Reville">Reville, F. Douglas. [http://brantford.library.on.ca/archive/index.php/archive/article/188 History of the County of Brant Vol. 1: Illustrated With Fifty Half-Tones Taken From Miniatures And Photographs], Brantford, ON: Brant Historical Society, Hurley Printing, 1920. Retrieved from Brantford.Library.on.ca 4 May 2012, PDF pp. 187–197, or document pp. 308–322. (PDF)</ref> Beneath the central bronze casting is a large carved inscription: "To commemorate the invention of the telephone by Alexander Graham Bell in Brantford 1874."<ref>[http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v101/n2523/abs/101005b0.html A Graham Bell Telephone Memorial], [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']], Vol. 101, 5-6, 7 March 1918, D.O.I.:10.1038/101005b0.</ref> Upon its public unveiling the Bell Memorial created a stir of controversy with its abstract allegorical interpretations.<ref name="Expositor-2010.07.26" /> Upon first viewing the bronze tableau, one observer in the crowds remarked on the two main figures on its left side, ''Man the Inventor'' and ''Inspiration''. "It looks to me..." he spoke to his friend, "...like an angel trying to pull along a pig-headed Englishman."<ref>Burrage, Walter. "Onlooker at Bell Unveiling", ''[[Brantford Expositor]]'', 6 March 1974.</ref> The monument also launched its designer-sculptor to fame. It was designed and crafted under [[Walter Seymour Allward]] (1875–1955), likely Canada's best monumental sculptor of the era.<ref name="NationalGalleryOfCanada">[http://national.gallery.ca/english/library/biblio/ngc008.html#a2 Walter S. Allward Collection: Finding Aid], [[National Gallery of Canada]] website. Retrieved 26 April 2012.</ref>{{#tag:ref|The [[National Gallery of Canada]] writes of Allard: "Walter Allward (1875–1955) was probably Canada's most important monumental sculptor in the first third of this century ... his most notable early success was the Alexander Graham Bell Monument (1908–1917) in Brantford, Ontario."|group="Note"}} Besides the Bell Memorial he created numerous other important monumental works, his greatest being the [[Canadian National Vimy Memorial]] in [[Pas-de-Calais|Pas-de-Calais, France]], commemorating Canada's sacrifices and human losses in the First World War, a project he worked on 16 years until its completion in 1936.<ref name="NationalGalleryOfCanada" /> The Bell Memorial is located within the Bell Memorial Gardens, a small park in downtown Brantford, in an area originally slated to be the city's new municipal centre, but which was subsequently built further away.<ref>Judd, David. [http://www3.brantford.ca/inventory.nsf/e6a90eb030f9a3d485256cfe006dc8bf/5e7fc98d512c1dc185256a8b0058610b/$FILE/DJudd%20on%20D&G%201914%20Report.doc It Could Have Been So Much More Different], ''[[Brantford Expositor]]'', 22 September 1990, pp. A5-A6.</ref> Other names considered for the park but which were not accepted included Bell Circle, Graham Bell Park and Prince George Park.<ref name="BEX-1909.09.29" />
== Reception == [[File:Bell Telephone Memorial, Alexander Graham Bell Park, Brantford, Ontario, Canada IMG 0417 18.JPG|thumb|right|Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada plaque added in 2010 honouring Allward's work.]]
Allward's memorial has been described as "a tour de force".<ref name="BEX-1936-08-10" /> One resident described the imagery of the oversized figures on its bronze panel, saying that it "...depicts a mythical passing of the spark of communication from the hands of the gods to the hands of humans".<ref>Murray, Gil. ''Nothing On But the Radio: A Look Back at Radio in Canada and How It Changed the World'', Dundurn, 2003, p. 22, {{ISBN|1550029924}}, {{ISBN|978-1550029925}}.</ref> The memorial has served as an important gathering point, landmark and commemoration site for Brantford, used to rally people for fund-raising events, marches and civic events. At the [[World War I#Armistices and capitulations|Armistice of World War I]], it became a spontaneous gathering point for celebration. It was also used to help raise funds for Brantford's First World War Cenotaph, another of Walter Allward's works.<ref name="Expositor-2010.07.26" />
The memorial received historical designation for its cultural heritage value, by the City of Brantford on 31 October 2005, under the ''[[Ontario Heritage Act]]''.<ref name="Historica">[http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/rep-reg/place-lieu.aspx?id=10785 Bell Monument], HistoricPlaces.ca website, retrieved 27 March 2012.</ref> It was also designated and listed on the [[Canadian Register of Historic Places]] on 12 January 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.historicplaces.ca/en/rep-reg/place-lieu.aspx?id=10785 |title=HistoricPlaces.ca |publisher=HistoricPlaces.ca |date=2005-10-31 |accessdate=2017-09-01}}</ref> In 2010 both [[Parks Canada]] and the Historic Sites and Monuments Board of Canada celebrated Allward's work by affixing a plaque to the monument honouring the sculptor himself. It noted Allward's designation as a person of national historic significance due to his "...original sense of spatial composition, his mastery of the classical form and his brilliant craftsmanship."<ref name="CP-2010.08.16">"Cdn Sculptor Walter Seymour Allward Honoured For His Public Monuments", [[The Canadian Press|''Canadian Press'']], 16 August 2010.</ref>

{{Infobox writer | name = Dilruba Ahmed | nationality = [[Bangladesh|Bangladeshi]]
[[United States|American]] | education = [[University of Pittsburgh]]
[[Warren Wilson College]] | genre = [[Poetry]] | years_active = 2011—present }} '''Dilruba Ahmed''' is a Bangladeshi American writer, educator, and poet.{{cite web|title=Dilruba Ahmed: Interview|url=http://www.triquarterly.org/interviews/dilruba-ahmed-interview|publisher=TriQuarterly|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en}} ==Early life== Dilruba Ahmed was born in the United States and grew up in western Pennsylvania and rural Ohio.{{cite news|title=Dilruba Ahmed: An Outsider Turns To Poetry|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/04/28/179026666/dilruba-ahmed-an-outsider-turns-to-poetry|accessdate=29 November 2017|work=NPR.org|language=en}} Her parents are from Bangladesh and immigrated to the United States. Her interest in poetry comes from her mother who used to practise poetry in Bangladesh. From her mother she learned the works of [[Rabindranath Tagore]] and [[Jibanananda Das]].{{cite web|title=An Interview with Dilruba Ahmed|url=http://www.americanliteraryreview.com/reviews--interviews/an-interview-with-dilruba-ahmed|website=The American Literary Review|accessdate=29 November 2017}} She completed her BPhil and MAT from the [[University of Pittsburgh]]. She graduated with MFA from the [[Warren Wilson College]]. She taught at the Low-Residency MFA program of the [[Chatham University]].{{cite web|title=Dilruba Ahmed|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/dilruba-ahmed|publisher=Poetry Foundation|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en-us|date=29 November 2017}}{{cite news|last1=Jennings|first1=Dana|title=Poetry by Kathleen Ossip, Tracy K. Smith and Others|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/08/30/books/poetry-by-kathleen-ossip-tracy-k-smith-and-others-review.html|accessdate=29 November 2017|work=The New York Times|date=29 August 2011}} ==Career== Dhaka Dust, a collection of Dilruba Ahmed poetry, was her first publication. In her poem she writes about the Bangladeshi American experience in the United States and also in Dhaka, Bangladesh.{{cite web|title=Book Review: 'Dhaka Dust' by Dilruba Ahmed|url=https://hyphenmagazine.com/blog/2011/9/14/book-review-dhaka-dust-dilruba-ahmed|website=hyphenmagazine.com|publisher=Hyphen Magazine|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en|date=14 September 2011}} Dhaka Dust won the 2010 Bakeless Prize for Poetry which was awarded by the Bread Loaf Writers.{{cite web|title=Shelf Awareness for Readers for Tuesday, June 28, 2011|url=http://www.shelf-awareness.com/readers-issue.html?issue=5#m112|website=shelf-awareness.com|publisher=Shelf Awareness|accessdate=29 November 2017}} The book was published in 2011 by Grey Wolf. The book was selected by Arthur Sze.{{cite web|title=Interview: Dilruba Ahmed|url=http://thecollagist.com/collagist-blog-archive/2010/4/17/interview-dilruba-ahmed.html|website=thecollagist.com|publisher=The Collagist|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en}} Her book has been anthologized in ''Literature: The Human Experience'' and in the ''Indivisible: An Anthology of Contemporary South Asian American Poetry''.{{cite web|title=Dilruba Ahmed|url=https://www.pw.org/content/dilruba_ahmed|website=pw.org|publisher=Poets & Writers|accessdate=29 November 2017|language=en}} Her book ''The 18th Century Weavers of Muslin Whose Thumbs Were Chopped'', deals with colonial repression by the [[British Raj]] in the Bengal.{{cite book|last1=Wong|first1=Mitali Pati|last2=Hassan|first2=Syed Khwaja Moinul|title=The English Language Poetry of South Asians: A Critical Study|date=2013|publisher=McFarland|isbn=9780786436224|page=175|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h7IDmx_v5YEC&pg=PA175&lpg=PA175&dq=Dilruba+Ahmed&source=bl&ots=VWblWH7_so&sig=Op1LsFz1hg3lSEOrn7WFAbXjA1g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiNq8y1weTXAhXGKWMKHdi9ATU4HhDoAQikATAZ#v=onepage&q=Dilruba%20Ahmed&f=false|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ahmed, Dilruba}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American people of Bangladeshi descent]] [[Category:Bangladeshi women academics]] [[Category:Bangladeshi women artists]] [[Category:Bangladeshi women poets]] [[Category:Bangladeshi women scholars]] [[Category:Bangladeshi historians]] [[Category:American women poets]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

'''Edmond François Paul Pottier''' (13 August 1855, [[Saarbrücken]] – 4 July 1934, Paris) was an [[art historian]] and [[archaeologist]] who was instrumental in establishing the [[Corpus vasorum antiquorum]]. He was a pioneering scholar in the study of [[Pottery of Ancient Greece|Ancient Greek pottery]].
He was born in [[Saarbrücken]], Rhineland, the son of a civil engineer he won a place at the [[Lycée Condorcet]] and went on to study at the [[École Normale Supérieure]] and the [[École française d'Athènes|École d'Athènes]], his thesis was on the subject of the chronology of Athenian [[archon]]s. It was during his tenure as a curator at the [[Louvre]] that he organised the first meeting of the [[Union Académique Internationale]] aimed at establishing the complete Corpus of [[Greek vase]]s held in the national collections of every nation in 1919. He produced the first fascicule for the Louvre in 1922.
Under the pseudonym [[Jacques Morel (writer)|Jacques Morel]] his wife was a writer who won the 1912 [[Prix Femina]] with the book ''Feuilles mortes''.
== Published works == In 1908 his book on the vase painter [[Douris (vase painter)|Douris]], ''Douris et les peintres des vases grecs'', was translated into English and published as "Douris and the painters of Greek vases".<ref>[http://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/001991646 Douris and the painters of Greek vases] HatiTrust Digital Library</ref> Other noteworthy works by Pottier include: * ''Étude sur les lécythes blancs attiques à représentations funéraires'', 1883 – Study on the white [[lekythoi]] of [[Attica (region)|Attica]]. * ''La nécropole de Myrina: recherches archéologiques exécutées au nom et aux frais de l'École française d'Athènes'', 1887 (with [[Salomon Reinach]]; A. Veyries; École française d'Athènes) – The necropolis at [[Myrina, Greece|Myrina]]: archaeological research performed on behalf of the French School of Athens. * ''Les Statuettes de terre cuite dans l'antiquité'', 1890 – [[Terracotta]] statuettes of ancient times. * ''Vases antiques du Louvre'', 2 volumes, 1897-1901 – Antique vases of the Louvre. * ''Diphilos et les modeleurs de terres cuites grecques'', 1908 – Diphilos and Greek terracotta modelers. * ''Le dessin chez les grecs d'après les vases peints'', 1926 – Greek design in regards to its painted vases. * ''L'art hittite'', 2 volumes, 1926-31 – Hittite art.<ref>[http://www.worldcat.org/identities/lccn-n84-076794/ Most widely held works about Edmond Pottier] WorldCat Identities</ref>
